description: From Middle English ilke, from Old English ilca, conjectured as from Proto-Germanic *ilīkaz, a compound of *iz and *-līkaz from the noun *līką (“body”). Akin to Dutch lichaam, or lijk, body, dead body.
The sense of “type”, “kind” is from the application of the phrase ‘of that ilk’ to families: the word thus came to mean ‘family’.

entries.meaning: A type, race or category; a group of entities that have common characteristics such that they may be grouped together.
examples: The cow is of the bovine ilk;
One end is moo, the other, milk.
